texts.definition: Games where the gameplay is clearly divided into clearly defined parts where players can plan and select actions
markups: <style="Definition">Games where the gameplay is clearly divided into clearly defined parts where players can plan and select actions</style>

Many games separate gameplay into easily understandable units where some actions are allowed and others not allowed. Most traditional games follow this pattern by letting one player plan and then execute an action as a turn and then letting another player do a turn, alternating until the game is finished. Turns are in this way typically used to describe periods of gameplay when one player can plan without risk of interruption to select and perform one action. However, this can challenged in various ways in games while still having them be perceived as having turns, e.g. by having several players do turns simultaneously, being able to do several actions, introducing time limits to make the actions, or letting other players have the possibility of interrupting turns.

Games with more complex structures of organizing gameplay can have turn-like structures on many levels. To distinguish between these rounds, phases, and segments are often introduced as concepts, while turns typically signify when players make important choices that need several steps to evaluate or get to make an uninterrupted series of actions. The players' perception of the gameplay is often the determining factor if a game is called turn-based rather than its internal structure. This is the case why not all computer games have seen as turn-based, even if they do have clearly defined states at all points due to being programs.

In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style>, the players take turns to move or place their pieces on the board. In the basic variant, there is no strict time limit for the players to execute their turns apart from social pressure exerted by the other player while in tournaments this may be enforced due to practical reasons. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diplomacy">Diplomacy</link></style> is an early example of letting players simultaneously have turns, alternating between letting them negotiate with each other for a predetermined period of time and then executing their chosen actions. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style> is a newer example where players simultaneously decide the next five actions for their robots and then execute them in parallel. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style> uses a similar structure, with each turn letting all players participate in a time-limited bidding in how few moves they can solve a movement puzzle, and then letting the lowest bidder show his or her solution in an ''proving'' phase.

The computer games <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Laser%20Squad%20Nemesis">Laser Squad Nemesis</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Combat%20Mission%20series">Combat Mission series</link></style> offer the players modes for hot-seating, switching the player whose turn it is, and sending the turn information via e-mail to the other player. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization</link></style> video game series has a turn-based structure in which a player may move all his or her units based upon an action point system, showing an example of more complex division of how to separate gameplay. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bloodbowl">Bloodbowl</link></style> does the same but enforces that one unit's actions are finished before activating the next unit.

The two-person board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Hulk">Space Hulk</link></style> also has a similar structure, but also has strict time limits on the player controlling the human marines. By introducing a time limited planning phase and an execution phase which replenishes the time limit, the single-player <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Hulk%20(video%20game)">computer-based version</link></style> can be seen as removing the turn-based structure since enemy actions also take place within the execution phase. Similarly, the board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style> has a real-time planning phase followed by a execution phase when they are executed. By separating all the planning and all the execution into two phases, the game also challenges the turn-based structure.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style> lets the active player chooses one action which then every player gets to perform, although the choosing player get a bonus. In this fashion, the game has a turn-based structure which is associated with one player but no player needs to wait long between being able to act in the game.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Peggle">Peggle</link></style> and pool games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eight-ball">Eight-ball</link></style> show that while some games are <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> the execution of events may take place in real time.
Wikipedia has a section on <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style><ref name="wikipedia"/>.

A primary choice when considering having turns in games is if this should be done in conjunction with <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> or not, since this can give rise to <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> (The pattern <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> discusses the effects of letting players alternate between being able to influence the game and different options on how to limit the actions possible within a turn). <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style> is an alternative to allow <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> but makes <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> more difficult and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> less direct.

An important aspect of <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> is what determines how a turn ends. Besides simply waiting until a player has finished (see <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> for options) or run out of actions due to <style="Link"><link="action-caps">Action Caps</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style>, one can introduce <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> which although not possible on an overall scale shows how <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> can have parts that work like <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>. For the <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> to serve a purpose, failing to finish ones actions before the given time need to be connected to <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, which can range from enforced <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style> through pre-determined or randomized actions to forfeiting the game. Another possibility is <style="Link"><link="turnovers">Turnovers</link></style>, having a turn end as a <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style> due to failing to perform certain actions, this is for example used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bloodbowl">Bloodbowl</link></style>.

Avoiding <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> requires that rules exists concerning all players rather than just one player to determine when turns end. This can simply be when all players have finished their possible actions according to any of the possibilities above, but this also makes <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style> a possibility (although mostly mitigated if common <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> are used). However, some purely group-based alternatives exist. Firstly, where <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> are typical examples, one can provide actions which have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diminishing%20Returns">Diminishing Returns</link></style> structures until all players prefer to do <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style>. Secondly, may or may not avoid <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="role-selection">Role Selection</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="token-placement">Token Placement</link></style> can let players choose what type of actions to do in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Planning%20Phases">Planning Phases</link></style> but then let all players do these actions in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Execution%20Phases">Execution Phases</link></style> (examples of this can be found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominant%20Species">Dominant Species</link></style>, [Egizia]], and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style>). Thirdly, which is typically a consequence of all players just done <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Planning%20Phases">Planning Phases</link></style>, is to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Execution%20Phases">Execution Phases</link></style> consisting purely of <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style> (found both in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diplomacy">Diplomacy</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style>).

Regardless of <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> effectively turn <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> into <style="Link"><link="tick-based-games">Tick-Based Games</link></style>. However, unless there are <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> it is easy for extra moments of planning time before the next turn begins unless the players have divided some of their attention from the actual gameplay.

Although <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> are on one level incompatible with <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, the execution of events started by actions as part of the turns can be shown in real-time; examples of games doing this is <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Peggle">Peggle</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Pool%20Games">Pool Games</link></style>.

Turns are not always easy to explain diegetically. Possibilities include seeing them as actions and re-actions, e.g. attacks and defenses, or as ways to model specific parts of the diegetics while avoiding otherwise, e.g. <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> in role-playing games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>. Turns can however work well as the mechanic that progresses time in the game world, see <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Turn-Based%20Games#Narrative%20Aspects">Narrative Aspects</link></style>.

The interface for <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> need to clearly indicate what actions are possible and which are not during any specific turn, and in many cases also show ''who's'' turn it is. This is actually even more important in <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style> since mistakes can be difficult to undo and may have revealed planned players actions, and some games provide special game tokens just to keep track of this (e.g. the governor card in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style>). In this way, the way turns are indicated in games are similar to how game modes are indicated. However, switching between game modes are typically voluntary (e.g. between a main interface and an inventory) while changes between different types of turns are results of game events.
<style="Link"><link="hotseating">Hotseating</link></style> is a way of supporting <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> on computers without requiring one computer per player.

For games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Gameplay%20Time">Limited Gameplay Time</link></style>, the remaining number of turns need to be presented if one wishes to support <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style>; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%204">Civilization 4</link></style> does this when nearing the set limit of turns.

Turns can easily be mapped to the progress of time to link gameplay to a narrative, and is commonly done in games with strategic or historic perspectives. These can have linear relations, e.g. each turn being half a year in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diplomacy">Diplomacy</link></style> or one hour in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hearts%20of%20Iron">Hearts of Iron</link></style> series, or change as gameplay progresses as in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization</link></style> series. While the latter does so independently of the actual gameplay that has taken place, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Origins:%20How%20We%20Became%20Human">Origins: How We Became Human</link></style> does not make an exact mapping (it state that one turn is approximately 10,000 years in the rules but this is not kept track of during gameplay) but instead puts players in different developmental categories.

Many goals and activities are fundamentally different depending on if the gameplay is <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time</link></style> or <style="CurrentLink">Turn-based</style>. <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> in <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> allow players to use more of their cognitive skills in compared to <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, as they have more time to think, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> of actions require more <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> skills than skills in <style="Link"><link="dexterity-based-actions">Dexterity-Based Actions</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> can easily give rise to <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, especially in those with <style="Link"><link="synchronous-gameplay">Synchronous Gameplay</link></style>, either due to waiting for other players in games with <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> or, for <style="Link"><link="tick-based-games">Tick-Based Games</link></style>, having completed their planning and actions well in advance of a fixed <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limit</link></style>. This <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> can provide <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> if the game supports <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style> respectively), but the presences of <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cognitive%20Engrossment">Cognitive Engrossment</link></style> can also be the cause of <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style> in the acting player. These effects are often less drastic in games with <style="Link"><link="asynchronous-gameplay">Asynchronous Gameplay</link></style> than those with in <style="Link"><link="synchronous-gameplay">Synchronous Gameplay</link></style>, as players have possibilities of non-gameplay related actions while waiting for other players to complete their turns. Those games without <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> may have the consequences mentioned above, but is less likely to since all players as the start of a turn have something to do. A possible disadvantage is however that the same player may be the cause of <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> repeatedly or that players start to engage in <style="Link"><link="guilting">Guilting</link></style> to avoid <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style> to occur.

<style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> make many activities, e.g. <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, that would be reaction or dexterity-based if performed ''for real'' instead be a form of <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>. That being said, <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> can give rise to <style="Link"><link="time-pressure">Time Pressure</link></style>, not only from explicit <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> but also from social pressure of other players in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> that are waiting for the next turn to begin. In contrast, <style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based</style> <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> allow a form of <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> and thereby a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> of when to play.

<style="CurrentLink">Turn-Based Games</style> make <style="Link"><link="interruptibility">Interruptibility</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style> very easy to introduce since there are clear break points, and it is easy for every player to be aware exactly where in the gameplay one was when game is to be continued. For the same reason, they are a basis for <style="Link"><link="asynchronous-gameplay">Asynchronous Gameplay</link></style> and provide a first basis for <style="Link"><link="negotiable-play-sessions">Negotiable Play Sessions</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="action-caps">Action Caps</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Execution%20Phases">Execution Phases</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="hotseating">Hotseating</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Planning%20Phases">Planning Phases</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="role-selection">Role Selection</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="token-placement">Token Placement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="turnovers">Turnovers</link></style>
